simplified: Dreams can help you understand thoughts you did not know you had. Many people have the same dreams, like flying, falling, teeth falling out, or having no clothes on in public. These dreams are often about the same kinds of feelings for many people. What do they mean for you? Think about what happened in your day and how you felt.

One of the most interesting examples of wild animals in a city is the wild dogs in Moscow. In this city, about 35,000 wild dogs live on the streets. Some dogs were born wild. Others were pets, but their owners abandoned them. Some dogs live alone, and others live in groups. In 2010, scientists studied these dogs. They found that the dogs have adapted very successfully to city life. The dogs learned that it is safer to cross the street with people, and some dogs maybe understand traffic lights.

Wonder is RJ Palacio's first novel. She is a writer from New York. She explains on her website that one day, she saw a girl on the street. The girl had facial deformities. This gave her the idea for the book.

Wonder has been a bestseller in the United States. It has also won several prizes. Many schools now use this book as a starting point for discussions. Teachers and students discuss bullying and friendship. They also discuss being different.

A film version is being made. Many people, including me, are waiting eagerly to see what RJ Palacio will write next.

Chloe has two pet rats. Their names are Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows that rats are not common pets. She has explained to people many times that rats are not dirty. She tells people that rats are great pets if you take care of rats well. But she understands why people react badly to rats.

Chloe didn't like rats before. Then her friend Martin showed her his pet rats. She saw that Martin's rats were friendly and smart. Last year, one of Martin's rats had babies. Chloe decided she wanted to have two of the baby rats.

Cape Town can be dangerous for baboons. Some baboons get hurt or die in car accidents. Others are electrocuted while playing with electric cables.

Baboons are an endangered species. To save them and make fewer problems between people and baboons, the city council has employed a team called Baboon Monitors. The team chases baboons out of the city, or catches them and takes them to areas outside the city.

This plan has had some success, but it is hard to stop baboons from coming back when they learn the city has easy food.

I work for a global IT company. Because the main office is in America, I work online from home. This is good because I don't spend time traveling to work. I also don't have to make small talk with colleagues.

I work on a project basis. This way of working gives me flexibility. This flexibility is very important to me. When my children have school shows, I can go. When I need to see the dentist, I can easily take time off.

But there is a problem. I don't have clear work hours. Because of this, I often work late in the evening. Sometimes I skip dinner to finish a task.

In the 1990s, graffiti continued, but there was also a big, sudden rise in street art around the world. Some artists wanted to talk about problems in the world. Their art made people think about war, inequality, and discrimination. Other street artists wanted to make beautiful work. In South America, many street artists worked in poor areas. They added colour, life, and beauty to the grey city walls.

Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people every day with things to buy. British people are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Online shopping makes it easy to buy without thinking. Major brands sell such cheap clothes that people can treat them like disposable items – worn two or three times and then thrown away.

Sam tried to see in the bright sun. Far away, a car went up to the Big House and made a trail of dust as it moved. The horses kicked and moved their tails at the flies. They did not care that their owner came for the first time in ten months.

Sam waited. Mr Carter only came here when he had to. This was good for Sam. The more he stayed away from his boss, the longer he would keep his job.

Mr Carter wiped the sweat from the back of his neck. Wet spots on his shirt drew together like shapes on a map. His skin was already getting red in the June sun. Usually he had the tan of a man who stayed inside and made money while other people did the work.

Many people in Berlin, Germany complained that shooting pigs was unnecessarily cruel. Hunters and animal lovers had angry arguments about this problem. Because of the protests, the city council decided to take more peaceful action against pigs. Instead of shooting them, the city council has put up fences and made it illegal to feed the pigs. Time will tell if this plan will work. It might be difficult because winters are getting warmer. When winters are warm, more pigs can live. There are more pigs than before because of the warmer winters.

An important inspiration for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne’s love of classical Greek myths. When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story, Crete rules the city of Athens, but the people of Athens fight back. To punish them, King Minos of Crete makes Athens send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. They are put into a maze with a monster that lives there. This monster is the Minotaur. It eats them. But one of them, named Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne thinks Katniss Everdeen is like Theseus, but in the future.

Zoos bring people and animals together. This helps people learn about saving animals and their homes. When people visit zoos, they might become interested in protecting animals and the places where animals live.

Some zoos are safe places for animals that had difficult lives. These animals might come from circuses where people hurt them. Some animals were pets, but their owners gave them up. Zoos give these animals a safe place to live.

Zoos also do important research. They watch how animals act. They study how to treat animal illnesses. This research helps many animals.

A new trend is growing against consumerism. This trend is called "Buy Nothing." The idea started in Canada in the early 1990s. Then it moved to the US.

In the US, this trend became a way to reject the overspending of Black Friday and Cyber Monday. These are special shopping days during Thanksgiving weekend. Many Americans spend too much and buy too much during this time.

On Buy Nothing Day, people organize different types of protests. Some people cut up their credit cards.

Throughout the year, Buy Nothing groups organize activities. People in these groups exchange items they already own. They also repair things instead of buying new ones.

Is graffiti art or vandalism? This depends on what you think, but in many countries, writing or painting on public or private property is against the law. The police have stopped many street artists. Some have had to pay fines. Many city councils complain that it costs a lot of money to clean graffiti from buildings, buses and trains.

What do people in the art world think about graffiti and street art? Recently, more and more people see it as real art. There were big street art shows in art galleries in Paris, London, and Los Angeles. The American artist Elura Emerald organized a street art exhibition in a New York gallery in 2008. She supported street artists and said, "Artists who paint on the street are only expressing themselves, not hurting anyone. They should be appreciated and celebrated."

Most people have four to six dreams every night after they are ten years old. That means as many as 2,000 dreams each year. So when a person is 80 years old, that person might have had 140,000 dreams in their life.

We forget about 95 to 99 percent of our dreams. But we still remember a few thousand dreams during our life.

Sometimes, a dream event is followed by a similar event in real life. It's not too difficult to believe this happens by coincidence, especially if the dream is about things that often happen in everyday life. When you have thousands of dreams, some of them will be similar to real events by coincidence.

The Hunger Games happens in the future. North America was destroyed. The country is now called Panem. Panem has twelve poor districts. The Capitol is rich and controls the country.

Each district must make different things for the Capitol. District 12 is where the story starts. This district provides all the coal for the country. There used to be thirteen districts. But District 13 rebelled against the Capitol. The Capitol destroyed it.

Wild animals often come into cities to find food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started coming into areas on the edge of the city.

The baboons open trash cans. They also eat fruit from people's gardens and orchards. Some brave baboons even go into houses and take food from kitchen cupboards and fridges!

Baboons can be aggressive. They have attacked a lot of pet animals. Because of this, many people in the city don't welcome them.

A lot of bridge accidents happen while people are building the bridge. This is often because engineers make a mistake, for example, a wrong calculation. The bridge can collapse under its own weight, and this can kill workers on the bridge at the time.

George Lucas was one of the first movie directors to use a story pattern called "the hero's journey." This pattern has 17 stages.

In this type of story, the hero starts the story living a normal life. Then something happens that changes everything. This is called "the call to adventure."

At the beginning of Star Wars, Luke lives a normal life with his aunt and uncle. He repairs robots. Then Luke finds a message inside a robot called R2D2. The message is from Princess Leia to Obi-Wan Kenobi. This message is "the call to adventure" that starts Luke on his journey.

Scientists have another idea to protect Earth from space rocks that might hit us. One idea is to blow them up using nuclear weapons. This might sound like a movie. In fact, there was a movie about this in 1998 called Armageddon. But NASA has a real proposal for this. It is called HAMMER (Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response).

HAMMER would use eight-ton rockets. Scientists would fire these rockets at a space rock coming toward Earth. They hope the rockets would bump it off course. But if the space rock is too close to Earth for this to work, the rockets would carry nuclear weapons to blow it up instead.

Campbell says the hero first says no to the call to adventure. Then a teacher or guide appears and helps. After that, the hero decides to ‘cross the threshold’ and enter a special world where the adventure happens.

Next, the hero takes tests, fights enemies, and meets friends. The hero gets ready to face the biggest challenge.

For Luke, the teacher is Obi-Wan, his friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO, the enemy is Darth Vader, and the special world is the Death Star.

Things you don't use much may seem useless to some people. But they could be useful to others. Online communities on the internet have found ways to make money from sharing these items. There are now websites and groups where people can buy and sell used items. These make it easier for people to buy and sell with each other. This is called the sharing economy.

Around the 1700s and 1800s, two main ideas about dreams became popular.

The first idea was that dreams show us things hidden from our conscious mind. A man named Freud believed this. He thought that if we understand our dreams, we can understand our hidden feelings. We can also understand the problems that come from these feelings.

The second idea was the opposite. It said that dreams are just random activity in our brain. This happens when our brain organizes memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to understand this random activity. We try to make it into a story.

I am a freelancer and work for myself. This is great because I can decide what I do and how I spend my time. At first, I worked at home, but it was hard to focus. There were many distractions around me: doing housework, making another cup of tea, and family members wanting my attention. So I went to a café near my home to work, but the Wi‑Fi was not good and I drank too much coffee. In the end, I decided to rent a desk in a co‑working space with five other people who also work for themselves. I liked getting dressed in the morning to go to work, and in the office, I could focus.

NASA needs money to build NEOCam. This is a 0.5-metre space telescope that uses infrared light to find asteroids. If NASA gets the money, it could probably find the remaining middle-sized NEOs in ten years.

Once these asteroids are logged, the team would still need to work out how to defend Earth. They need to work out how to defend the planet against the truly worrying asteroids – the PHAs.

The 'buy nothing' trend has now reached influencers on social media. These influencers usually share posts of clothes and make-up that they tell others to buy. But now, some YouTube stars tell the people who watch them not to buy anything. They encourage them not to buy things for periods as long as a year.

Two friends in Canada tried this. They spent one year working towards buying only food. For the first three months, they learned to live without buying electrical goods, clothes, or things for their home. 

For the next stage, they stopped paying for services. They did not get haircuts. They did not eat at restaurants. They did not buy petrol for their cars. After one year, they saved $55,000.

Religion is important to Pi. His family is Hindu, but he is curious about other religions. He becomes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. Pi surprises everyone when he says he is Hindu, Muslim and Christian at the same time.

His family and teachers ask him to choose only one religion. Pi refuses. He tells them, "I just want to love God." After that, they let Pi make his own mind up about religion.

Some people believe that writing down your dreams can open your mind to lucid dreams. In lucid dreams, you know that you are dreaming. You can also make choices to change what happens in your dream.

For example, if you have a bad dream, you can make it feel safe. You can guide your dream like a film director guides a film.

When you have lucid dreams, you will be creating them. But you might want to have some other dreams too. These dreams let your subconscious show you what's on your mind.

People may not know they are part of the disposable clothing problem because they give their unwanted clothes to charities. But charity shops cannot sell all these clothes. 'Fast fashion' means clothes that go out of fashion as quickly as they came in. These clothes are often too poor quality to recycle. People don't want to buy them when they are used.

Huge quantities of clothes end up being thrown away. A lot of clothes that charities can't sell are sent abroad. This causes even more economic and environmental problems.

Some adventurers today go from one challenge to another. One example is Meagan McGrath from Canada. She has climbed the highest mountain on every continent. She has also ridden a bike across Canada. She has run a very long race in the Sahara Desert in 45°C heat.

Perhaps her most remarkable journey was a skiing trip to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a deep crack in the ice. She had to be rescued. Many of us would have given up at that point. But Meagan decided to continue. She reached the South Pole after forty days. She pulled a sledge with her tent and all her food behind her. She traveled through freezing conditions and ice storms.

Blek le Rat started by painting pictures of rats on walls in Paris. Paris is his home city. Now, he tries to make people think about different problems. He paints pictures of people who don't have homes in big cities. He does this to make people think about the problem. Many people don't have a place to live.

In some places, councils encourage artists not to paint graffiti randomly on walls. They let artists paint in designated areas instead. Taiwan is one example. There are “graffiti zones” where artists are free to paint and write on walls. In São Paulo, Brazil, the city council even lets some graffiti artists paint on the city’s subway trains.

Faith47 is from Cape Town, South Africa. She paints big, colorful pictures of people and animals. She likes to explore different places. You can find her art on pavements, in empty factories, and on abandoned cars. She likes that most street art does not last long. The weather or city workers remove it. For her, this shows that life is full of change. It is a cycle: things end, and new things begin.

In her old job, Gabriela worked in a high power distance culture, where leaders had a lot of power. People respected leaders and did not often question them. Everyone knew their place. Leaders made the big decisions, and people did not often ask why.

Her Swedish team was used to a low power distance culture, a different way of working. There, subordinates and bosses often work together to find answers and make decisions. Here, leaders are like coaches. They want people to think for themselves, ask questions, and speak up.

Gabriela noticed that she and her team had different cultures. She decided to talk with them. She asked them how they felt about the way she led the team.

Her team was happy that she asked for their opinions. They told her that they were not used to being told what to do. They liked having more freedom to try new things. When Gabriela told them exactly what to do, they felt that she didn't trust them to do their job well.

The team also realized something. When they tried to change Gabriela's decisions, she took it personally. But the team explained that this was normal for them. They had always worked this way. It was not personal. It was just how they worked.

Os Gêmeos are identical twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint many different things. Sometimes they paint small graffiti marks. Sometimes they paint very big, colourful pictures of people on the sides of buildings.

Their work is often very big. It is so big that the brothers need special machines called cranes. These machines help them work.

In 2007, they covered the whole of a castle in Scotland with paint.

People have painted and written on walls for a very long time. In prehistoric times, people in Africa and Europe painted pictures of animals and people in caves.

People have found graffiti at ancient sites in Greece, Italy, Syria and Iraq. In Pompeii (an old Roman town), archaeologists have found many graffiti written in Latin. The graffiti included religious, political and romantic messages. Some were even magic spells!

Have you ever wanted to climb Mount Everest? Have you ever wanted to walk to the South Pole? If so, you are not alone. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the highest mountains in the world or walk across continents.

In the past, explorers used maps and compasses. Today's adventurers use modern technology like GPS and satellite phones.

Many adventurers love nature. They use their travels to raise awareness about environmental issues. Other adventurers want to help people in need. They raise money for charities.

The first test is called DART. This stands for Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Scientists plan to test DART on the moon of an asteroid called Didymos. This moon is also called "Didymoon."

Didymoon is 150 meters wide. It goes around Didymos, which is 800 meters wide. Scientists plan to crash DART into Didymoon. They hope this impact will change Didymoon's orbit enough. If it works, telescopes on Earth will hopefully pick up this change.

The main character of the story is Katniss Everdeen. She is sixteen years old. Her father died in a mining accident, so she must provide food for her family. She goes hunting in the forest near District 12. Her friend Gale goes with her. She becomes very good at using a bow and arrow.

Her younger sister Prim is chosen as one of the tributes. Tributes are young people who must fight. But Katniss goes instead of her sister. The other tribute from District 12 is a boy named Peeta. Soon, Katniss finds herself in a complicated relationship with him.

Write about your dreams. This will help you remember more details. Think about the people and the place in the dream. They might add to the meaning. Over a week, you will be surprised at how much you have written down. Now you can start to connect your dreams to the events and the feelings in your daily life.

In the past, more bridges were made of wood. These wooden bridges could catch fire easily. This was especially true for old-fashioned train bridges. When trains moved, the steel wheels and steel tracks made sparks. Sometimes these sparks started fires. The fires could burn the whole bridge to the ground.

We don't know what will happen to street art in the future. But we can see some trends happening now.

Most street artists are young people. They usually paint in their own city or neighbourhood. But now, more artists are traveling to different countries to work.

Street artists also use the internet. They talk to each other online. They share photos of their work.

Another change is happening. More people are giving recognition to street art. They see it as a legitimate art form.

We don't know what will happen to street art in the future. But one thing is clear. Street art is here to stay!

Suzanne Collines has always found news about wars upsetting. When she was a child, her father was a pilot in the American Air Force. He fought in Vietnam. Her mother tried to protect Suzanne by not telling her what was happening in the war. But Suzanne still saw news programmes about the war. She knew her father was in Vietnam. This was very frightening for her.

Two big companies did global studies. PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) got more than 40,000 responses. Some responses were from millennials. Millennials were born between 1983 and 1993. Other responses were from non-millennials.

They asked about many topics. These topics included workplace culture and communication. They also asked about working styles, pay structure, and career development. Work-life balance was another topic.

Deloitte did a different global study. They asked more than 10,000 millennials questions. These millennials shared their perceptions about threats and opportunities at work. The world of work is complex.

Erik Weihenmayer is from the United States. He is an adventurer who does many different activities. He has ridden a bike through the deserts of Morocco. He has kayaked through the Grand Canyon. He has also climbed Mount Everest. Amazingly, Erik has been blind since he was 13 years old.

Erik does more than just travel. He tries to encourage people who cannot see or walk to be active. He takes groups of young blind people on climbing trips.

Online platforms now give people a chance to make extra money. In the past, busy parents might not have bothered to sell their children's old equipment at local markets. But now, online marketplaces make it possible.

Parents can now sell baby clothes that their children have outgrown. These clothes are often almost new because babies grow quickly. Parents can also sell expensive baby items like strollers. They spent a lot of money on these things, so selling them helps them get some money back.

With online marketplaces, parents don't need to set up a stall at a market or car boot sale. This way of selling helps parents put some cash back into their pockets.

Pi and Richard Parker stay in the lifeboat for 227 days. They don't have enough food. They get sick and very tired. They live through terrible storms and the burning heat of the Pacific sun, but somehow they stay alive. Sometimes Pi finds comfort when he thinks about his three religions. But sometimes he feels overcome with loneliness and despair. Finally, they can see the Mexican coast. Everything changes. It would be a shame to tell you the ending. You should read the book yourself. Then you will know what happens to Pi and Richard Parker when they get close to land.

Chloe came home from school. She made a cup of coffee and took it to her bedroom. She had homework to do, but that could wait for later. She wanted to enjoy the quiet hour before her parents came home. When they arrived, the house filled up with evening sounds. There were sounds of people chatting, the television, and her dad listening to his beloved jazz music while he cooked dinner. She also liked this time of day because she could play with her pet rats.

In 2010, NASA’s space team found and recorded 90 per cent of the space rocks (asteroids) near Earth that are 1 kilometre wide. These near-Earth objects (NEOs) are as big as mountains. An object is near Earth when it comes within 50 million kilometres of Earth’s orbit (its path around the Sun). With about 50 left to find, NASA says the 887 asteroids they now know about are not a big danger to Earth.

Auggie decides to go to school. He feels very worried, like all children at a new school. But Auggie looks different from other children. This makes his first day very painful.

On his first day, nobody wants to sit next to him. He sees other kids looking at him. They talk about him behind their hands. Luckily, he makes friends with Jack, a boy in his class. He also becomes friends with Summer, a girl who chats with him at lunch.

The first day is difficult, but the other days are hard too. Auggie learns that his classmates don't want to touch him. They are afraid they will catch "the plague" (a bad sickness).

During the school year, Auggie has many intense ups and downs. Then something unexpected and very bad happens at a school camp. This event changes everything for Auggie.

The two men looked to the north end of the land. The land stretched as far as they could see. Even from where they stood, the fences were hard to see. A teenage boy might feel bored and want to rebel, but it was not possible to escape on foot. Sam looked at the biggest horse. It was kicking the ground with its heavy hooves. He wondered if the boy could ride. A good rider could get into a lot of trouble out here, miles away from anyone. But someone who knew nothing about horses and wanted to get away from his father could get into even more trouble.

More than 4,000 climbers have climbed to the top of Mount Everest. These climbers are between 13 and 80 years old. Climbing high mountains is still extremely dangerous because of freezing weather and violent storms. But the best climbers in the world now look for new things to try.

Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner is from Austria. She fell in love with mountain climbing when she was a teenager. After she left school, she worked as a nurse. She still went climbing in her free time.

After climbing Everest, Gerlinde decided to climb all fourteen 8,000-meter mountains in the world. To make it harder, she climbs without extra oxygen. This is dangerous because there is not much oxygen at the top of high mountains, and it can hurt the brain and body. Gerlinde is famous for climbing, and she uses her fame to help a charity for poor children and orphans in Nepal.

If we look at the things we have bought, we can see that we do not use all of them. For example, we bought a thick wool coat because we thought it looked trendy, even though we live in a hot country. Another example is the smartphone that got put away when we bought a new model. There is also a car that we use only on weekends. We even have a guest room in our house that became a room for storing things we do not use.

Throughout history and across cultures, dreams have been connected with prophecy. People thought dreams were messages from the gods. The gods sent these messages to give us knowledge or help us understand things. Even today, many people can recall a time they dreamed about an event, place or person. Later, the dream came true in real life.

Some of the biggest and most expensive transportation projects in the world have involved building bridges. Bridges are very important because they help cars, trucks and trains go across water, mountain gorges or other roads.

Bridges are one of the most important parts of civil engineering. They are subject to intense scrutiny, especially when they collapse.

Gabriela was frustrated with her team for many weeks. She emailed her Swedish manager about the problems she had with her team. Her manager simply wrote back with two questions. First, he asked if her team was still performing. Second, he asked what could help her work better with her team.

Gabriela found her manager vague. She did not feel he was managing the situation satisfactorily.

Dogs that live in groups know that people often give food to small, cute dogs. Because of this, the group sends these dogs to ask for food for everyone. Some dogs even use the city metro to go from one part of their area to another.

Scientists are not sure how the dogs know when to get off the train. One idea is that they use their very good sense of smell and know the smells of their favourite places. Another idea is that they have learned the station names and know them when someone says them on the train. Now, people on the metro are used to seeing dogs on the trains, and they often do not pay much attention to them.

Ed Stafford from the UK is the first person to walk the length of the Amazon River. He started at a small stream in the Andes mountains of Peru. He arrived at the river's mouth in Brazil. The walk took two years and four months. He walked 6,000 kilometres.

The Amazon rainforest has poisonous snakes, crocodiles and jaguars. So Ed was always in danger. Luckily, he survived with nothing worse than a few thousand mosquito and ant bites.

In Britain, the average person spends over £1,000 on new clothes each year. This is about 4% of their income. It may not sound like a lot, but it hides two big problems for people and for the environment.

First, many people buy clothes with credit cards. In Britain, each adult has about £670 in credit card debt. This is 66% of the average clothes budget for one year.

Also, people spend money they do not have to buy clothes they do not need. Britain throws away 300,000 tons of clothes every year, and most of it goes to landfill sites.

Ed’s walk would have been impossible without technology. He used a radio to ask local people in the rainforest for food and to ask if he could cross their land. Many people met him and helped guide him through the hardest parts of the forest. As he walked, Ed wrote a blog about what happened each day. There was media interest in his trip. He used this to speak against the destruction of the rainforest and to raise money for environmental and children's charities in Brazil and Peru.

Many companies now see they can make good money from the sharing economy. They do not share things themselves. They act as a middleman and help people rent out things they do not use all the time.

One popular way is to make a website or app that connects people who need a room or a ride with people who can offer one. Airbnb helps people rent out empty rooms and houses. People rent out these rooms and houses as places to stay and can earn extra money. Uber lets people offer rides with their own cars, so they can make extra money in their free time.

Today, zoos have an important job. They run international breeding programs to help animals have babies. These programs focus on endangered species.

In the wild, some very rare animals cannot easily find a partner and have babies. They also face danger from poachers, from the loss of their homes, and from other animals that kill them. A good zoo gives these animals a safe place to live and have babies.

Also, when the number of wild animals goes down, there is a bigger risk that many animals are closely related. These zoo programs can help protect the species. Animals born in zoos can be released into the wild and increase genetic diversity.

These accidents are very rare, but boats and trains can make a bridge fall for different reasons. For trains, a very fast, strong hit can make the bridge fall. For boats, their very big weight can make the bridge fall, even when the boat moves very slowly. The best way to avoid bridge accidents is to plan for them. Modern technology can find weak parts in a bridge. Safer workplaces and better bridge plans can also help. Together, they can make these bad accidents happen less often.

At first, Pi is very afraid of the animals and jumps into the sea. Then he remembers there are hungry sharks in the water near him, and realises that his only choice is to climb back into the lifeboat. After that, one by one, the animals in the lifeboat kill and eat each other. Soon, only Pi and the tiger are left. Pi names the tiger Richard Parker. Fortunately for Pi, the tiger is feeling sick on the boat and does not want to eat him right away.

When Pi is 16, a new government is elected. His parents don't like it. They are worried about the future. Pi's parents decide to close their zoo and move to Canada.

They sell some animals to zoos in North America. The family travels to Canada by ship. They take some animals with them.

During the trip, there is a terrible storm. The ship sinks. Pi's family all drowns. The sailors also drown. But Pi finds himself in a lifeboat. He is not alone. There is a hyena, a zebra, an orang-utan and a very big tiger in the boat with him.

The Hunger Games is a very successful book for teenagers and young adults by the American writer Suzanne Collins. Since it was published in 2008, it has sold millions of copies around the world, and it is now available in 26 languages. It was also the first book for young readers to sell more than one million e-books.

The Hunger Games is now a big Hollywood film, and it is very successful. It made more than 150 million dollars in the first weekend in North America alone.

Maybe dreams happen because our mind organises the thoughts we have during the day. In dreams, these thoughts can have special meanings. When we are awake, we mostly think in words, like talking to ourselves. But when we sleep, the part of the brain that controls language is less active, and the part that controls emotions is more active.

Good relationships are very important for happiness. One study showed that most happy people have strong ties with friends and family. They make sure they spend time with these people often.

You also need at least one person you can talk to about your feelings. Talking about your feelings with someone is called "self-disclosure." You need just one person to share your feelings with. You also need a network of other relationships.

It is not enough to have many friends just to do things with. You need more than friends to chat with about music or football. You need that deeper connection with one person. The deeper connection is the most important thing.

Some people need to learn how to listen better. When you listen well to others, you can have stronger relationships.

Carol Dweck is a psychologist. She talks about "growth mindset" - the idea that our brains can change and grow. She says we can learn new skills and talents, even if we are not good at them at first.

Many people like to praise others for their natural talents. For example, we might say "You are really good at seeing small details" or "You are great at organising events." We often praise the final result and what people are naturally good at.

But research suggests we should think about this differently. When we praise how people do things - their hard work, trying new ways, and how they solve problems - we can help them learn. This kind of praise helps people learn new skills. It also helps them get better at things they already do well.

So instead of only praising talent, we should praise effort. We should notice when someone works hard, tries new ways, or solves problems. This way of praising helps people keep learning and get better.

The rover checks the air around it regularly. In 2014, it found methane in the air. Methane is one of the most basic organic molecules. It is also a key part of natural gas.

Methane is special because it only stays in the air for a few hundred years. After that, it breaks down. But there is still methane on Mars. This means that something on Mars is replacing it.

NASA says that Mars releases thousands of tons of methane at a time. The amount of methane goes up and down during different seasons of the year. It is almost as if the planet is breathing it.

Carol Dweck is a psychologist at Stanford University. Early in her career, she gave some ten-year-old children problems. These problems were a little too difficult for them.

One group of children liked this. They said they loved difficult problems. They understood that they could learn and get better. Dweck says these children have a "growth mindset." This means they think about what they can do in the future.

But another group of children felt their intelligence was being judged. They felt like they had failed. These children have a "fixed mindset." They could not think about improving.

Some of these children said they might cheat in the future. Others looked for someone who had done worse than them. This made them feel better about themselves.

Horror films love places where no one lives. This can be an old empty hospital, a scary empty house, or a town with no people. There is something strange about these lonely, empty places. These places make you wonder. What was it like when people lived there? Why did they leave? Maybe they are so quiet, and that can be very scary. Of course, these empty places are useful for horror movie makers, because it is easy to believe there is no phone signal there.

In horror movies, basements are always scary. It doesn't matter what type of house has the basement. Usually, something is hiding there. Sometimes, the evil person has hidden tools in the basement.

Basements are always dark. They are often damp too. You can only reach them by narrow stairs. Basements feel scary even when there isn't anything down there.

Gary Collins was an off-duty policeman watching the riots in London on TV. He immediately recognized several people, so he ended his holiday early and went to help pick out people.

He spent six months looking at videos from cameras. He picked out 190 people. He recognized many just from their eyes. His help was very important for the investigation. There were 200,000 hours of video, but a face recognition computer found only one person.

I find it interesting how we can make our bodies better. This will help people evolve faster.

Imagine if we could put a computer inside our brains. Soon, we will be able to put a computer in our brains! The computer will help us with math. It will help us see and hear better. It will make our memory stronger too.

This idea will become more and more common in the future.

The talk was very interesting. The speaker was right about a couple of things. For example, she talked about how parents affect their children. Parents use their phones while they cook dinner or wait at traffic lights. They write messages on social media. So how can we expect teenagers not to text while they do homework? Their parents use phones at the same time as other activities too.

The speaker made another good point. People want to be in two or several places at the same time. They move between real-life conversations and online conversations. They go back and forth.

I see this with my teenage daughter and her friends all the time. They plan to meet. When they meet, they sit together. They sit together in silence. Each person has different online conversations at the same time.

News stories often make us think the world is becoming more violent. But there is some good news too. Between 1945 and 1990, there were 30 wars. Each war killed more than 100,000 people. Today, civil wars still happen. But countries mostly get along more peacefully than before.

However, attacks by violent groups have increased a lot in recent years. Since World War II, wars have killed many more civilians than soldiers. But even for civilians, the numbers are not all bad. Deaths from violent crime are nine times more likely than deaths from political conflict. The good news is that the global murder rate fell slightly. In 2000, about 8 people out of every 100,000 were murdered worldwide. In 2015, this global rate went down to about 5.3 people out of every 100,000.

Wasfia has spent her life working for human rights. She has seen many international projects in Bangladesh that teach women and girls new skills. But these projects often stop, and the women and girls are left with nothing.

Wasfia saw that her country needed to stand up for itself. She loves two things: climbing mountains and working for human rights. She decided to use both to change how people think about women in Bangladesh.

She started climbing when she was working on humanitarian campaigns in Tibet and Nepal. Bangladesh is a coastal country that is mostly flat. Most people there have never seen a mountain.

Now her campaign is working. People in Bangladesh are starting to see what she is doing. The rest of the world is watching too.

Many people think that developing countries are in a very bad situation. They think these countries have very poor people, dictators, and little hope for big change. But this is far from the truth. Big changes are happening.

In the last 20 years, more than 700 million people have increased their income. They have come out of being poor. Also, six million fewer children die each year from disease. Millions more girls go to school now. Millions of people have access to clean water.

The situation is not as bad as many people think.

Many managers try to add some positivity to their feedback. They use a "sandwich" pattern: first a good comment, then a bad comment, then another good comment. But when this pattern becomes routine, employees can start to see the good comments as sugarcoating the bad part. Then the good comments lose value. Positive feedback should not just make the negative feel smaller. Positive feedback should be given to reinforce and encourage good work.

I am a member of the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Don't think about scary robots from movies. Think about what is happening now. Military machines like drones, gun turrets and sentry robots are already being used to kill people without much help from humans.

The next step will be robots that can decide who to kill by themselves. They will follow orders, but they will choose who to kill on their own. It seems clear to me that this is completely wrong and dangerous for all people. We need to be very careful about what we ask machines to do.

More people are learning English than all other languages combined. English is also spoken in more countries than any other language. But Chinese has the most native speakers - far more than any other language.

There seems to be little connection between the number of native speakers and the number of people learning a language. But there is a connection between the number of learners and the number of countries where people speak that language.

Your manager stops you and says she needs to talk to you about your performance on the recent project. You worry all weekend and think, “What did I do wrong?” On Monday morning, you go into her office. She starts by saying good things about your work on the project. You wonder if these nice words are just the start of what people call a “feedback sandwich.” You know how it goes: first, you hear something nice. Then you hear the thing they really want to say. Then you hear something nice again.

Born in the USA is a rock album with fast music that makes you want to move your feet. But the words of the songs have emotional weight. The songs have catchy rock music, but they talk about the dark side of the American dream.

Many songs are about normal, hard-working people. These people work a lot but life doesn't bring them riches or glory. They feel angry and bitter.

For example, the song Glory Days is about people in a small town. They remember when they were young and felt they could do anything. Another song, Downbound Train, is about a young man who loses his job. After that, his life is ruined.

When you listen, you can think that the singer knew these people. Maybe he would have the same life if he hadn't become a famous musician.

This album will leave you in no doubt of the unique and extraordinary talent of the Boss.

Lewis wants more parts of the ocean to be protected. Right now, 3 percent of ocean areas are protected. He wants this to grow to 10 percent. He hopes this will help fix the damage that people have caused. These problems are catching too many fish, polluting, and throwing trash in the ocean.

Lewis has seen these problems himself during his expeditions. He has swum over coral (the colorful rock-like homes where fish live) that turned white because the water got too warm. In the shallow parts of the Red Sea, he saw areas under the water that looked like deserts. There were no fish or plants there, and plastic trash was scattered around.

Pugh thinks nature can get better if we give it protected space. But we don't have much time. If we don't start taking care of our seas now, we may soon have a problem that we cannot solve.

Terrie Sharp is a best-selling writer. She writes crime stories. She has won the Olive Crime Writer Award two times.

Terrie was born on a housing estate in Glasgow. This area had the highest crime rate in Glasgow. When she was young, she learned to keep quiet and stay out of trouble. She also learned things like how to open car doors with a knife.

Luckily, Terrie only uses what she learned to write her books. She doesn't do these things. She only uses them for her stories. Her books sell very well.

Terrie is not so quiet these days. She goes on television shows during the day. One show is called Police Today. She also goes to writing conferences all over the UK.

Are things getting worse every day? Is progress impossible? In his book "Enlightenment Now," Steven Pinker looks at the big picture of human progress. He finds good news. We are living longer and healthier lives. We have more freedom and we are happier.

But Pinker says there is a real problem. The Enlightenment values of reason and science are under attack. Some commentators and demagogues appeal to people's tribalism. They appeal to people's fatalism. They appeal to people's distrust.

When this happens, we are in danger of causing irreparable damage to important institutions. We can cause irreparable damage to democracy. We can cause irreparable damage to world co-operation.

In old scary movies, it was hard or impossible for people in danger to call for help. They could not easily call the police. Today, many people have mobile phones. So this situation is a bit less believable in new movies. How do movie makers maintain suspense? No phone signal!

If you are the main character in a scary movie today, it is almost certain that your phone will fail. At the most important moment, when you really need help, you will not have any signal at all. Or your battery will die just as you are making the call. Sometimes both things happen at the same time.

In the 1950s, commercial banana growers in Central America had a big problem. Their most profitable product, the Gros Michel banana, was dying. People called it Big Mike. Now the same thing is happening to Big Mike's replacement, the Cavendish.

The Gros Michel was easy to transport because it had thick skin, and it was sweet. It became the main banana on farms in Central America.

At that time, United Fruit was the main grower and exporter of bananas. The company grew bananas in the most efficient way it could. It did not grow plants from seeds. It cloned shoots from the stems of plants to make new plants. The company grew them very close together in big fields.

Most spiders have venom. They use it to stun or kill the small animals they eat. Spiders use venom for catching food, not for attacking people. Only 25 of the known types of spiders have venom that can hurt humans. Spider bites can hurt, but they rarely kill people.

Australia has a dangerous spider called the Sydney funnel-web spider. Since 1981, when doctors made anti-venom for its bite, no one has died from it.

Be careful with hairy spiders like tarantulas. Do not rub them the wrong way. When these spiders feel they are in danger, they shoot out a cloud of small hairs. These hairs cause problems. They stick in the skin or eyes of the attacker.

This scary movie pattern was very common in horror films of the 1980s and 1990s. It starts with a group of teenagers having fun together. By the end, everyone is dead except one girl.

At first, this girl is usually innocent and shy. She is not particularly strong. But by the end of the movie, she becomes the toughest and most resourceful person in the world. The last girl almost always wins.

To understand how humans developed complex language, we need to study how our brains are different from animal brains. This is not just about brain size. We also need to know what our brains can do that is different. We need to understand when these skills appeared and why they developed.

It is difficult to find information about this. The tools and objects that early humans left behind don't tell us what speech they were capable of making. Scientists can look at the remains of early humans and see the development of the mouth, throat and tongue.

By about 100,000 years ago, humans could make complex sounds. Before that time, scientists can only guess whether or not early humans used more basic sounds.

It is society, not nature, that says girls should choose art and languages, and boys should study maths and physics. There is also a lack of positive female role models in science jobs for children to see. In cartoons and stories, the crazy scientist, the very smart person who makes new things, or the brave astronaut is often a man. Many people also think scientists are strange, do not talk well with other people, or work alone, away from other people. These ideas come from the media, and they are not true. So, many girls do not connect with scientists. They think science is not a good job for them. If girls see more good examples of women in science, they will be more confident and feel they can do these subjects.

The Scallion is a student newspaper. It comes out every week and is free in faculty buildings. About 10,000 students read it.

Only students write and make this newspaper. A survey shows that university students and staff highly value the newspaper. They value it for entertainment. It also gives them cultural enrichment. The newspaper is valued for work experience.

Printing the newspaper costs a lot of money. Also, some students do not have easy access to the paper. The only way to get a copy is to physically go to university.

There is another problem. A large number of copies end up as litter on campus. This is bad for the environment.

At Girox Foods, about 12% of our workers leave or lose their jobs every year. This might not seem high at first, but the normal rate for companies like ours is 7%. This report will look at what makes workers engaged at our company. Based on what we find, we will offer suggestions to make working here better and keep more employees.

I agreed with many things the speaker said. I think there is a danger that when we are more connected, we can feel more alone.

For my generation, this is not a big problem. We lived many years without technology. We know how to be alone, and we know it is OK to be alone.

But people under 20 are different. They are so busy communicating that they do not experience the feeling of being alone. They may not learn to enjoy time by themselves.

Also, they learn conversation through messages. They can edit and change these messages. So, they do not practice real conversation in real time with a person in front of them.

Don't always give good feedback followed by bad feedback. When you always say something good and then something bad, people stop caring about the good things. They ignore them.

Sometimes, just tell people what they did well. Don't add criticism. It's important to give good feedback without saying what could be better.

There are times when you should only say good things. Don't try to help people improve every time you praise them. Let the good feedback be enough sometimes.

Dreams can show you all kinds of insights into thoughts you didn't know you had. Many people have similar dreams. For example, flying, falling, your teeth falling out, or having no clothes on in public. These common dreams probably have similar meanings for most people. But to understand exactly what your dreams mean for you, you need to connect them to what happens in your everyday life and how you feel.

One of the most interesting examples of wild animals living in a city is the wild dogs of Moscow. About 35,000 wild dogs live on the streets of Moscow. Some dogs were born wild, while others used to be pets that their owners abandoned. Some dogs live by themselves and others live in packs.

In 2010, scientists studied these dogs. The dogs have adapted remarkably successfully to urban life. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street when people cross. Some dogs even seem to understand traffic lights.

Wonder is the first novel by RJ Palacio, a writer from New York. On her website, she explains how she got the idea for the book. One day, she saw a girl on the street who had facial deformities. This gave her the idea for the story.

Wonder has become a bestseller in the United States. It has already won several awards. Many schools now use this book as a starting point for discussions. Teachers and students discuss bullying, friendship, and what it's like to be different.

A film based on the book is being made. Many people, including me, are waiting eagerly to see what RJ Palacio writes next.

Chloe has two pet rats called Zena and Roxy. She knows they're not common pets, and she has lost count of how many times she's patiently tried to explain that rats aren't dirty. They make wonderful pets if you take care of them properly. But she understands why people react badly. She didn't like rats either until her friend Martin showed her his pet rats and she saw how loving and smart they were. Last year, when one of Martin's rats had babies, Chloe decided she'd like to have two of them.

Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some baboons have been hurt or killed in car accidents. Others have died from electric shocks when they played with power cables. Baboons are an endangered species. To save the baboons and reduce conflicts between people and baboons, the city council has hired a team of Baboon Monitors.

The monitors' job is to chase baboons away from areas where people live. Sometimes they catch baboons and release them in the countryside. This policy has had some success. However, it is hard to stop baboons from coming back to the city once they see it as a source of easy food.

I work for an international IT company. The main office is in the United States, but I do all my work online from home. This means I don't waste time traveling to work or making small talk with colleagues. I work on a project basis, and this way of working is very valuable to me. It means I can easily take time off when my children have school events or when I need to schedule an appointment with the dentist.

The downside is that I don't have clear working hours. Because of this, I often work late into the evening. Sometimes I skip dinner to finish a task.

In the 1990s, graffiti continued, but there was also an explosion in street art around the world. Some artists wanted to share political messages through their art. They tried to make people think about war, inequality and unfair treatment. Other street artists cared more about making beautiful art. In South America, many street artists went to work in poor areas. They added colour, life and beauty to grey city walls.

Social media, magazines, and shop windows bombard people every day with things to buy. British people are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. Online shopping makes it easy to buy without thinking. Big brands sell clothes that are so cheap that people treat them like things to throw away, wearing them two or three times and then throwing them away.

Sam looked at the dust trail made by the car on its way to the Big House. The sun was bright, and he had to squint to see better. The horses kicked and moved their tails to keep flies away. They didn't care that their owner's first visit was happening after ten months.

Sam waited. Mr Carter only came here when he had to, and that was just fine by Sam. If he kept out of his boss's way, he would keep his job longer.

Mr Carter wiped sweat from the back of his neck. His shirt had wet spots that came together like shapes in an atlas. His skin was already turning red in the June sun. Otherwise, he had pale skin like someone who worked inside. He made money while other people did the work.

Many people living in Berlin, Germany complained that shooting pigs was cruel when it was not needed. There were heated arguments between hunters and animal lovers. Because of the protests, the city council decided to take more peaceful action against the pigs. Instead of shooting them, they have put up fences and made it illegal to feed the pigs. Time will tell if this strategy works. However, it may be a losing battle because warmer winters mean that pig numbers are greater than in the past.

An important idea for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne’s love of classical Greek mythology. When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was Theseus and the Minotaur. In this story, Crete rules the city of Athens, but the people of Athens fight against Crete. To punish them, King Minos of Crete makes them send seven boys and seven girls to Crete every year. The young people are thrown into the labyrinth, where a monster called the Minotaur lives and eats them. But one of the young people, Theseus, fights the Minotaur and kills it. Suzanne sees Katniss Everdeen as a futuristic Theseus.

Zoos bring people and animals together. This gives zoos a chance to teach the public about conservation problems and to encourage people to protect animals and their habitats. Some zoos offer a safe place for animals that were treated badly in circuses or for pets that were abandoned by their owners. Zoos also do important research. They study how animals behave and how to treat illnesses.

A different trend is growing against consumerism – it's called the 'Buy Nothing' trend. This idea started in Canada in the early 1990s and then spread to the United States. There, it became a rejection of the overspending and overconsumption of Black Friday and Cyber Monday during Thanksgiving weekend. These are shopping days during Thanksgiving weekend.

On Buy Nothing Day, people organize different kinds of protests. Some people cut up their credit cards. Throughout the year, Buy Nothing groups organize the exchange and repair of items they already own.

Is graffiti art or vandalism? Different people think different things about this. In many countries, when people write or paint on walls or buildings that belong to others, it is against the law. Police have stopped many street artists. Some artists had to pay money as punishment. People who run cities say it costs a lot of money to clean graffiti from buildings, buses and trains.

What does the art world think of graffiti and street art? Recently, more people have started to see its value as an art form. There have been major shows of street art in galleries in Paris, London and Los Angeles. In 2008, an American artist called Elura Emerald organized a street art show at a gallery in New York. She defended street artists and said, "Artists who paint on the street are just expressing themselves. They are not hurting anyone. They should be valued and celebrated."

After age ten, most people have four to six dreams every night. That is up to 2,000 dreams in one year. By the time a person is 80, they may have had around 140,000 dreams. Even if we forget almost all of our dreams, we still remember a few thousand in our lifetime. So it is not hard to believe that, by coincidence, a dream is followed by a real-life event that is similar to it. This is especially true if the dream is about something that happens often in daily life.

The Hunger Games happens in the future, after North America was destroyed. The country is called Panem. It has twelve poor districts that are controlled by the rich Capitol. The Capitol has complete power over the nation. Each district is responsible for producing something different for the Capitol. District 12, where the story starts, provides all the coal for the country. There used to be a thirteenth district, but they rebelled against the Capitol and were destroyed.

Wild animals often come into cities to look for food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started coming into neighborhoods at the city's edge to feed. They open garbage cans and eat fruit from people's gardens and orchards. Some brave baboons have even come into people's houses and taken food from cupboards and fridges! Baboons can be aggressive and have attacked many pets. So, many city residents don't want them around.

Many bridge accidents happen while the bridge is being built. These accidents often happen because engineers make an error, like making a wrong calculation. The bridge collapses because it cannot support its own weight. This can be deadly for the workers on the bridge at that time.

George Lucas was one of the early movie directors to directly base his story on the 17 stages of the hero's journey. Usually, the hero begins by living a normal life. Then something happens that calls them to go on an adventure. This adventure changes everything.

At the start of Star Wars, Luke Skywalker lives a normal life with his aunt and uncle, repairing robots. When he finds a message from Princess Leia to Obi-Wan Kenobi inside the robot R2D2, this is the "call to adventure" that starts the hero on his journey.

Scientists have another idea to protect Earth from a dangerous asteroid that might hit us: using a nuclear weapon to destroy it. This might sound like something from a movie. In fact, it was the story of the 1998 film Armageddon. But NASA has a real proposal called HAMMER.

The HAMMER proposal uses eight-ton rockets. Scientists would launch these rockets at an asteroid that is coming toward Earth. The goal is to push the asteroid off course. If the asteroid is already too close to Earth for this plan to work, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs. These bombs would blow it up instead.

Campbell says that at first, the hero refuses the call to adventure. But then a mentor appears who helps them. After the mentor helps, they decide to 'cross the threshold' and travel into the 'special world' where the adventure takes place.

In the next stage, the hero faces tests, fights enemies, and meets friends. All of this prepares them for their biggest challenge.

In Luke's story, Obi-Wan is his mentor. His friends are Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO. His enemy is Darth Vader inside the 'special world' of the Death Star.

Things we don’t use much may look useless to some people, but they can be useful to others. Thanks to the internet, online communities have created a way to earn money from sharing these underused things. By using websites and social media groups that help people buy and sell used items, it is now easier than ever for people to share with each other. This is called the sharing economy.

Around the 18th and 19th centuries, two main ideas about dreams became popular.

The first idea was that dreams represent things that are hidden from our conscious mind. Freud believed that if we understand our dreams, we can discover our hidden feelings and the problems they cause.

The second idea was the opposite. It said that dreams are just random brain activity. While our brain organizes memories and events from the day, it creates random images and feelings. When we wake up, we try to understand these random images and feelings by putting them into some sort of story.

I am a freelancer and work for myself. This is great because I control what I do and how I spend my time.

At first, I worked from home, but it was hard to concentrate. There were too many distractions: housework, making another cup of tea, and family members wanting my attention for various things.

So I went to a nearby café to work. But the Wi-Fi wasn't ideal, and I drank too much coffee.

In the end, I rented a desk in a shared office with five other freelancers. I liked getting dressed for work in the morning, and I could focus better in an office.

Whether NASA can find the rest of the medium-sized near-Earth asteroids depends on getting the money to build NEOCam. NEOCam is a 0.5‑metre space telescope that uses infrared (heat‑sensing) light to find asteroids. If NASA gets the money, NEOCam could probably reach this goal in ten years. After NASA records the asteroids, the planetary defence team would still need to work out how to stop the most dangerous ones—PHAs (Potentially Hazardous Asteroids)—from hitting Earth.

The 'buy nothing' trend has now reached social media influencers. These people usually share posts about clothes and make-up that they recommend for people to buy. But now, some YouTube stars are telling their viewers not to buy anything at all for periods as long as a year.

Two friends in Canada spent a year working towards buying only food. During the first three months, they learned how to live without buying electrical goods, clothes, or things for their home. In the next stage, they stopped paying for services too. This meant no haircuts, no going to restaurants, and no petrol for their cars. By the end of the year, they had saved $55,000.

Religion is important to Pi. His family is Hindu, but Pi wants to learn about other religions too. He becomes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. Pi surprises everyone. He says he is Hindu, Muslim and Christian at the same time. His family and teachers ask him to choose only one religion. But Pi refuses. He says, "I just want to love God." From that moment, his family and teachers let Pi make his own mind up.

Some people think that writing your dreams down can help you have lucid dreams. A lucid dream is a dream where you know you are dreaming, and you can choose what happens. For example, you can change a nightmare into a dream that feels safe, or you can control the story of the dream like a movie director. Instead of only trying to understand your dreams, you can also create them while you dream. But you may still want some dreams that happen naturally. They can tell you what's on your mind.

People might not realise they are part of the disposable clothing problem. They donate their old clothes to charities. However, charity shops cannot sell all the unwanted clothes they receive.

'Fast fashion' goes out of fashion as quickly as it came in. These clothes are often too poor quality to recycle. People don't want to buy them second-hand.

As a result, huge quantities of clothes end up being thrown away. A lot of clothes that charities cannot sell are sent abroad. This causes even more economic and environmental problems.

Some of today's adventurers don't stop after just one amazing trip. They are not happy with just one trip and go from one challenge to another. Meagan McGrath from Canada has climbed the highest mountain on every continent. She has also ridden a bike across Canada and run a long race in the Sahara Desert in 45°C heat.

But her most amazing journey was her skiing trip to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a deep crack in the ice. Someone had to rescue her. Many of us would have given up after that, but Meagan decided to continue. For forty days, she pulled a sled with her tent and all her food behind her. She travelled through very cold weather and ice storms. Forty days later, she reached the South Pole.

Blek le Rat began painting rats on the walls of his home city, Paris. Today, he tries to make people think about different social problems. He paints pictures of homeless people in big cities. These paintings encourage city residents to think about the problem of homelessness.

In some places, local councils encourage artists not to paint on walls randomly. Local councils do this by letting artists work in special areas. For example, in Taiwan there are 'graffiti zones' where artists are free to paint and write on walls. In São Paulo, Brazil, the city council has even allowed some graffiti artists to paint on the city’s subway trains.

Faith47 is an artist from Cape Town in South Africa. She creates large, colourful paintings of people and animals. She enjoys exploring different locations. You can find her artwork on pavements, inside empty factories, and even on abandoned cars.

She likes that most street art doesn't last forever. Rain, wind, and cleaners from the city council will soon remove it. Faith47 likes this because it shows how life is full of change. Just like her art that doesn't last, life has endings and new beginnings.

In her old workplace, Gabriela was used to a culture where power and authority were respected. Everyone had their rightful place in the company. In this type of culture, bosses make the important decisions. People rarely challenge their bosses.

Her Swedish team was different. They were used to a culture where power differences are smaller. In her Swedish team, employees often work together with their bosses to solve problems and make decisions. The team's bosses act more like coaches. They encourage their team members to think for themselves. They also expect people to challenge them.

Gabriela noticed the cultural differences between her and her team. She decided to talk with them about their feelings about her leadership. Her team was happy that she asked for their opinions. They explained that they were not used to being told what to do. They enjoyed having more room to make their own decisions and be creative. When Gabriela gave them exact instructions, they felt that she didn't trust them to do their job well.

The team also realized that Gabriela was taking it personally when they tried to challenge or make changes to her decisions. They explained that this was how they had always worked.

Os Gêmeos are identical twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint everything from tags to huge, colorful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their work is often so big that they need cranes to help them work. In 2007, they covered the whole of a castle in Scotland with paint.

People have painted and written on walls for thousands of years. Long ago, people in Africa and Europe used to paint pictures of animals and people in caves. People have found graffiti on old buildings in Greece, Italy, Syria and Iraq. In Pompeii, an old Roman town, people who study the past have found many examples of graffiti. The graffiti was written in Latin. It includes messages about gods, politics and love. It even includes some magic spells!

Have you ever dreamed of climbing Mount Everest or walking to the South Pole? If so, you're not alone. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the world's highest mountains or walk across large areas of land. Unlike explorers in the past who used maps and compasses, today's explorers travel with new tools like GPS devices and special phones that work everywhere. Many explorers love nature and use their travels to raise awareness about different environmental problems. Others want to help people in need and raise money for charities.

The first test is called DART – the Double Asteroid Redirection Test. Plans are scheduled to test DART on the moon of an asteroid called Didymos. This moon is 150 metres wide. It orbits its 800-metre mother asteroid. When DART hits the moon, scientists hope the impact will knock it out of its orbit enough for Earth-based telescopes to detect the change.

The heroine of the story is Katniss Everdeen, a sixteen-year-old girl. Her father died in a mining accident. She must provide food for her family. She hunts in the woods around District 12 with her friend Gale. She becomes very good at using a bow and arrow.

When her younger sister Prim is chosen as one of the "tributes," Katniss volunteers to take her place. The other tribute from District 12 is a boy called Peeta. Soon, Katniss finds herself in a complicated relationship with him.

Writing about your dreams will help you start to remember more details about your dreams. Think about the people and place where the dream happened because they might add to the meaning. After writing for a week, you will be surprised by how much you have written down. Now you can start to connect your dreams with the events in your daily life and how you feel.

In the past, more bridges were made of wood than today. These wooden bridges were much more likely to catch fire than other types. This was especially true for old-fashioned train bridges. The steel wheels on steel tracks created sparks. Sometimes these sparks could cause the bridge to catch fire and burn to the ground.

We cannot know how street art will change in the future, but certain trends are emerging. While most street artists are young and paint in their own city or area, more artists now travel and work around the world. Many street artists also use the internet to talk to each other and share photos of their art. Galleries, museums, and art critics are giving street art more respect and see it as real art. Even if we do not know the future of street art, we can be sure it is here to stay.

Suzanne Collines has always found news programmes about wars very hard to watch. When she was a child, her father was a pilot in the US Air Force, and he fought in Vietnam. Her mother tried to protect her and did not tell her what was happening in the war. But Suzanne still saw the war on the news and knew her dad was there. It was a very frightening experience for her.

Two companies did global surveys about workers. In these surveys, millennials were defined as people born between 1983 and 1993.

PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC) did a global survey. More than 40,000 millennial and non-millennial responses were collected. They asked about several workplace topics. These included workplace culture, communication, working styles, pay structure, career development, and work-life balance.

Deloitte did another global survey. More than 10,000 millennials took part in it. The survey looked at what millennials think about the threats and opportunities in the complex world of work.

Erik Weihenmayer from the United States is a multi-adventurer. He has ridden a bike through the deserts of Morocco, kayaked through the Grand Canyon, and climbed Mount Everest. Amazingly, Erik has been blind since he was 13 years old. Apart from his travels, he tries to encourage people with disabilities to live active lives. He also takes groups of young blind people on climbing expeditions.

Online platforms that are open to everyone now make it easy for people to earn a quick bit of money. For example, busy parents might not have bothered with the effort of setting up a stall at local markets or car boot sales before. But with online marketplaces, parents can sell their children's hardly worn baby clothes that they have outgrown. They can also sell expensive baby items like strollers and other things they bought for their babies. This helps them put some cash back into their pockets.

Pi and Richard Parker spend 227 days (more than seven months) in a lifeboat. They live through hunger, sickness, and great tiredness. They face strong storms and the very hot Pacific sun, but they still survive.

Sometimes, Pi finds comfort in his three religions. Other times, he feels very lonely and without hope. Finally, the Mexican coast appears, and everything changes.

The ending is not given here. You need to read the book to find out what happens to Pi and Richard Parker when they see land.

Chloe came home from school, made a cup of coffee and took it to her bedroom. She had some homework to do, but it could wait. She wanted to enjoy the quiet hour before her parents came home and the house filled up with the evening sounds of talking, the TV, and her dad’s favorite jazz while he cooked dinner. She liked this time of day, too, because she could play with her pet rats.

In 2010, NASA's planetary defense team found and recorded 90 percent of the asteroids near Earth that are about 1 kilometer wide. These asteroids are as big as mountains. They are called "near-Earth objects" or NEOs. NEOs include anything within 50 million kilometers of Earth's orbit.

NASA believes there are about 50 more of these large asteroids that they still need to find. However, they have already identified 887 of them. NASA says none of these 887 asteroids are a significant danger to Earth.

After deciding to go to school, Auggie faces his first day. Like any child at a new school, he is very nervous. Because of how he looks, the day is an awful experience. No one wants to sit next to him, and he sees other kids stare at him and talk about him behind their hands. Luckily, he becomes friends with Jack, a boy in his class, and Summer, a girl he talks to at lunch. But it is not only the first day that is hard. Auggie soon learns that his classmates do not want to touch him because they are afraid of catching “the plague.” During the school year, he has many intense ups and downs. In the end, an unexpected and traumatic event at a school camp changes everything.

The two men looked towards the northern end of the property. It went on as far as they could see. Even the fences were barely visible from where they stood. It wasn't possible for a teenage boy to escape by walking, even if he was bored and wanted to run away. Sam looked at the largest horse, which was kicking at the ground with its heavy hooves. Could the boy ride? He wondered. A good rider could get into a lot of trouble out here, miles away from other people. But perhaps there was even more trouble for someone who didn't know anything about horses. Especially if that person wanted to get away from his father.

More than 4,000 climbers have reached the top of Everest. They are aged from thirteen to eighty. Climbing high mountains in freezing weather and violent storms is still extremely dangerous. But the world's best climbers now look for new challenges.

Gerlinde Kaltenbrunner comes from Austria. She fell in love with mountain climbing when she was a teenager. When she left school, she worked as a nurse. She kept climbing mountains in her free time.

After climbing Everest, Gerlinde decided to climb all fourteen of the world's 8,000 metre peaks. To make it more difficult, Gerlinde climbs without oxygen tanks. This is dangerous because low oxygen levels at the top of high mountains can affect how the brain and body work. Gerlinde uses her fame as a climber to support a charity for poor children and orphans in Nepal.
