Look at the things you have bought over the years. You will no doubt see that not everything you own is being put to good use. Maybe you have a thick woollen coat that looked trendy, even though you live in a tropical country. Maybe you have an old smartphone that you put away when you bought the newest model. You might have a car that you only drive on weekends. Or maybe you have a guest room in your house that somehow turned into a storage room.

For a long time, in many cultures, people saw dreams as signs about the future. They thought dreams were messages from the gods that gave us information or ideas. Even today, many people remember dreaming about an event, a place, or a person, and then, later, the dream came true in real life.

Many of the biggest and most expensive transport projects in the world involve building bridges. Bridges are very important links. They carry cars, trucks, and trains over rivers or seas, over deep valleys, or over other roads. So they are one of the most important parts of civil engineering (the work of designing and building roads, bridges, and other structures), and people check them very carefully, especially when they collapse.

After weeks of feeling upset, Gabriela sent an email to her Swedish manager about the problems she was having with her team. Her manager simply asked her if she thought her team was still performing. He also asked her what she thought would help her work better with her team members. Gabriela found her manager unclear. She didn't feel that he was handling the situation in a satisfactory way.

Some dogs live in packs. They have learnt that people are more likely to give food to smaller, cuter dogs. Because of this, the pack sends these dogs to beg for food for everyone. Some dogs even use the city metro to go from one part of their area to another. Scientists are not sure how they know when to get off the train. One idea is that they use their very good sense of smell and remember the smells of their favourite places. Another possibility is that they know the station names they hear in the announcements. Either way, passengers are now used to seeing dogs on the trains, so most local people don't notice them.

Ed Stafford from the UK is the first person to walk the length of the Amazon River. He started by a small stream in the Andes Mountains of Peru. Two years and four months later, he arrived at the river's mouth in Brazil, having walked 6,000 kilometres.

The Amazon rainforest is home to poisonous snakes, crocodiles and jaguars. So Ed was in constant danger. Luckily, he survived with nothing worse than a few thousand mosquito and ant bites.

In Britain, the average person spends more than £1,000 on new clothes each year. That is about 4% of their income. This may not sound like a lot, but this number hides two far more worrying trends for society and the environment.

First, much of this spending is on credit cards. Currently, British adults owe about £670 each on credit cards. That is about 66% of the average wardrobe budget.

Also, people are not only spending money they do not have, but also buying things they do not need. Britain throws away 300,000 tons of clothing each year, and most of it goes to landfill sites.

Ed's walk would have been impossible without technology. He used a radio to ask the people living in the rainforest for food and permission to walk through their land. Many of these people came to meet him and helped guide him through the most difficult terrain.

During his journey, Ed wrote a blog. He recorded what happened to him each day. The media were interested in his trip. Ed used this to speak out about the rainforest being destroyed. He also raised money for groups that help the environment and children in Brazil and Peru.

Companies have discovered that the sharing economy can be very profitable for them. They want to make money by helping people use resources that are not being used all the time. A popular business model works like this: companies create online platforms that connect customers with people who can offer products or services.

Airbnb is a good example. This company helps connect people who have unused rooms or houses with people who need a place to stay. The owners can rent out their unused spaces and make good money from them.

Another example is Uber. This company encourages people to use their personal cars as taxis. Drivers can make extra money in their free time by giving rides to people who need to go somewhere.

Today, zoos have one of their most important jobs: they support international breeding programs for endangered animals. In the wild, rare animals often struggle to find partners to breed with. They also face dangers like poachers, loss of homes, and predators. Good zoos give these animals a safe place to live and breed.

As animal numbers drop, there is an increased danger. The animals might become too similar to each other genetically. This is bad for the species.

Breeding programs in zoos provide a safeguard against this problem. Zoos can raise animals and then release them into the wild. When these zoo animals are released, they increase genetic diversity. In this way, zoos help protect species that are in danger.

These two types of accidents are extremely rare, but boats and trains can cause bridges to collapse for different reasons. When trains hit a bridge, it's the speed of the impact that can bring the bridge down. When boats hit a bridge, it's because they have very large mass that can cause it to collapse, even if they are moving slowly when it happens. The best way to avoid bridge collapses is to plan for them. New technologies can detect structural weakness in bridges. Safer working conditions and better bridge designs can also help reduce these terrible accidents.

At first, Pi is very afraid of the animals and jumps into the ocean. Then he remembers there are hungry sharks in the water, so he knows his only choice is to climb back into the lifeboat. One by one, the animals in the lifeboat kill and eat each other. Only Pi and the tiger are left. Luckily for Pi, the tiger is seasick. He names the tiger Richard Parker. The tiger does not want to eat him immediately.

When Pi is 16, a new government is elected that his parents don't support. They worry about the future, so Pi's parents decide to close the zoo and move to Canada. They sell some animals to zoos in North America. The family travels to Canada by ship and takes some of the animals with them.

During the journey, there is a terrible storm and the ship sinks. Sadly, Pi's family and the ship's sailors all drown. But Pi finds himself in a lifeboat with four animals: a hyena, a zebra, an orang-utan, and a huge tiger.

The Hunger Games is a hugely successful book for teenagers and young adults. The American author Suzanne Collins wrote it. Since the book came out in 2008, it has been translated into 26 different languages. It has sold millions of copies around the world. It is also the first book for young readers to sell more than one million e-books.

The Hunger Games is now a major Hollywood film. The movie is just as successful as the book. In its opening weekend in North America, the film made 152.5 million dollars!

Dreams might happen because our mind organizes the thoughts we have during the day. But these thoughts appear in dreams with special meanings. When we are awake, our thoughts usually come to us as words, like conversations we have with ourselves. But when we sleep, the part of our brain that controls language becomes less active, while the part that controls emotions becomes more active.

Having good relationships is very important for happiness. One study found that most happy people had strong connections with friends and family. Happy people make sure to spend time with friends and family regularly.

You also need at least one person to share your personal feelings with. Just one person for deep conversations is enough, along with a network of other relationships. It's not enough to have many friends only to do things with or to talk about things like music or football. That deeper connection is all-important.

Some people need to learn how to listen effectively to others. This skill helps them build stronger relationships.

Carol Dweck is a psychologist who believes in something called 'growth mindset'. She says that our brains can change and develop. This means we can learn new skills and talents, even if we weren't good at them at first.

Many people tend to praise what seem like natural talents and final results. For example, we might say "You're really good at noticing small things" or "You have a real talent for organising events". We focus on what seems to be an ability that someone was born with.

However, research suggests something important. Instead of praising the final result, we can encourage development by praising the process. We can praise people's effort, their experiments with new methods, and their problem-solving. When we do this, we encourage people to develop new skills and continue improving their talents.

This approach helps people keep learning and growing.

The rover checks the air around it from time to time. In 2014, it found methane in the air. Methane is one of the most basic organic molecules and an important part of natural gas. 

One thing about methane: it only lasts for a few hundred years. This means that something on Mars must be adding to the supply. NASA says that Mars releases thousands of tons of methane at a time. 

The amount of methane goes up and down during seasons of the year. It almost seems as if the planet is breathing it.

Carol Dweck is a psychologist at Stanford University. Early in her career, she gave ten-year-old children problems that were a bit too difficult for them to solve.

One group of children liked this. They said they loved challenges. They understood that they could get better over time. Dweck says these children had a "growth mindset." This means they focus on what they can learn in the future.

But another group felt that their intelligence was being judged. They believed they had failed. These children had a "fixed mindset." They could not imagine improving. Some said they might cheat in the future. Others looked for someone who did worse to feel better about themselves.

Horror films love places where no one lives. This could be an old empty hospital, a scary empty house, or a town with no people. There is something about lonely, empty places. What was it like when people lived there? Why did they leave? Maybe it is also that they are so quiet, which can be scary. Of course, these abandoned places are also useful for horror film directors because it seems more realistic when there is no phone signal there.

In horror films, the basement is scary in any house. Usually, something is hiding there, or an evil killer has hidden their tools there. Basements are always dark and often damp. You can only reach them by a narrow staircase. Basements are always scary, even when nothing is down there.

Gary Collins, an off-duty policeman, was watching the London riots on TV. He quickly recognized several people and ended his holiday early to help with identification. He spent six months going through the CCTV film and identified 190 people, many just by their eyes. His help was very important for the investigation. Even with 200,000 hours of video, face recognition software found only one person.

I find it really interesting to think about how we'll speed up how humans change over time by adding technology to our bodies. Imagine if you could put a computer inside your brain? Soon we'll be able to do exactly that. This technology will improve our math skills, help us see and hear better, and make our memory stronger. This idea will become more and more common.

The talk was very interesting and the speaker was exactly right about a couple of things. For example, think about how parents affect their children. How can we expect teenagers not to text while doing homework when they see their parents posting on social media while cooking dinner or waiting at a red light? The speaker also made a good point about people wanting to be in two or several places at the same time. Because of this, they keep switching between real-life and online conversations. I see it all the time with my teenage daughter and her friends. They plan to meet, but then they sit together without talking. Instead, each person is having a different conversation online.

News stories often make us think the world is becoming more violent, but there are some positive signs too. From the end of World War II until 1990, there were 30 wars where more than 100,000 people died. Today, civil wars still happen, but countries mostly co-exist more peacefully than in the past.

Terrorism has increased a lot in recent years. Since World War II, wars have killed many more civilians than soldiers. But even for civilians, the statistics are not all bad.

For civilians, deaths are nine times more likely to come from violent crime than from political conflict. The global murder rate fell slightly from 2000 to 2015. In 2000, about 8 people per 100,000 were murdered. By 2015, this number fell to about 5.3 people per 100,000.

Wasfia has dedicated her life to working for human rights. She has seen many international humanitarian projects in Bangladesh that help educate and train women and girls. However, these projects too often end, leaving the women and girls with nothing.

Wasfia realized that Bangladesh needed to stand up for itself. She decided to bring together two things she loves: mountain climbing and human rights. She wanted to use these to change attitudes towards women in her country.

Wasfia first took up climbing when she was working on humanitarian campaigns in Tibet and Nepal. This was unusual because Bangladesh is a coastal, mostly flat country. Most people there have never seen a mountain.

Her campaign seems to be working. People in Bangladesh are starting to pay attention to what she is doing. The rest of the world is also noticing her efforts.

Most people think that developing countries are in a very bad situation. They believe these countries suffer from extreme poverty, are controlled by dictators, and have little hope for meaningful change. But surprisingly, this is far from the truth. In fact, these countries are going through big changes.

In the last 20 years, more than 700 million people have increased their income and escaped poverty. Also, six million fewer children die from disease each year. Millions more girls now go to school, and millions of people have access to clean water.

Many managers try to make feedback more positive by using a common method. They put negative feedback between two positive comments. However, when this becomes a routine, employees can start to see positive feedback as just a way to sugarcoat the negative feedback. This makes positive feedback less valuable.

Positive feedback should not simply be seen as something to cushion the negative. Instead, managers should give positive feedback to reinforce and encourage good work. This helps employees continue doing well.

I belong to the Campaign to Stop Killer Robots. Don't think about scary robots from movies that kill people. Instead, think about what is happening today. Military machines like drones, gun turrets, and guard robots are being used to kill people. These machines work with very little human input.

The next step will be robots that kill on their own. These "murderbots" will follow orders, but they will decide on their own who to kill. It seems clear to me that this would be completely wrong and dangerous for all people. We need to be very careful about what we ask machines to do.

Overall, more people are learning English than all other languages combined. English is also spoken in more countries than any other language. However, Chinese has many more native speakers than any other language.

There seems to be little connection between the number of native speakers a language has and how many people learn it. There is a stronger connection between the number of learners and the number of countries where that language is spoken.

Your manager stops you and says she needs to talk about your performance on the recent project. You worry about it all weekend, wondering what you might have done wrong. On Monday morning, you step into her office. She starts by praising your work. You wonder if this is the obligatory praise that starts the typical 'feedback sandwich'. You know how the feedback sandwich goes: first, say something nice. Then, say what you really want to say. Finally, say something nice again.

Born in the USA is a rock album with fast, energetic music that makes you want to tap your feet. But the lyrics tell serious and emotional stories. The catchy rock songs talk about the dark side of the American dream.

Many songs on the album are about ordinary working people who struggle in their daily lives. These people work hard but don't get riches or glory. They feel angry because life hasn't given them what they hoped for.

For example, the song Glory Days is about people in a small town who remember when they were young. Back then, they felt they could do anything with their lives. Another song, Downbound Train, tells the story of a young man whose life is ruined when he loses his job.

When you listen to these songs, you can imagine that the artist is channelling real people he knew. Perhaps he's thinking about the life he might have had if he hadn't become famous. The album will leave you in no doubt of the Boss's special talent.

Lewis wants to increase the number of marine protected areas in the world from 3 percent to 10 percent. This is an attempt to reverse the damage that humans have caused by overfishing, polluting, and littering.

During his expeditions, Lewis has seen this damage to nature himself. He has swum over coral reefs that have turned white because the water temperature has increased. He has also seen underwater deserts beneath the shallow waters of the Red Sea. There is no life there and plastic is strewn around.

Lewis believes that nature can recover if we give it space to do so, but the clock is ticking. If we don't start looking after our seas, we may soon have a problem that we cannot solve.

Best-selling author Terrie Sharp is very good at telling stories. She has won the Olive Crime Writer Award twice. She was born in the neighborhood with the highest crime rate in Glasgow. There she learned to keep quiet, to stay out of trouble, and to open car doors with a knife. Luckily, she has only used this knowledge to write her novels. These days, she is not so quiet. She appears on popular TV shows during the day, like Police Today, and at events for writers across the UK.

Are things getting worse every day? Is progress impossible? In his book Enlightenment Now, Steven Pinker looks at human progress and finds good news. We are living longer, healthier, freer, and happier lives. The real problem, Pinker says, is that the Enlightenment values of reason and science (clear thinking and evidence) are under attack. Some writers and leaders appeal to people's tribalism, fatalism, and distrust. When this happens, we risk causing harm that cannot be fixed to important institutions, like democracy (people voting) and world co-operation (countries working together).

In old horror movies, when the main characters were in danger, it was difficult or impossible for them to call for help or call the police. Mobile phones have made this situation a bit less believable now. So how do movies keep the excitement? They use a simple solution: no phone coverage! If you're the hero in a horror movie, it's almost certain that at a key moment, just when you need to call for help, you won't have any coverage at all. Or your phone battery will die while you're trying to make the call. Or both.

In the 1950s, banana companies in Central America had a serious problem. Their most important banana type, the Gros Michel (also called Big Mike), was dying. Now, the same thing is happening to the banana that replaced it – the Cavendish.

The Gros Michel banana was very good for business. It had thick skin that protected it during transport, and it tasted sweet. These banana plants dominated the plantations of Central America. United Fruit was the main company that grew and exported bananas in South America at that time. The company mass-produced its bananas in the most efficient way possible. Instead of growing new plants from seeds, it made copies of existing plants. It took shoots from the stems of plants and planted them close together in densely packed fields.

Most spiders have venom that they use to stop or kill the insects and small animals they eat. The purpose of this venom is for catching prey, not for attacking people. Only 25 of the known spider species have venom that can hurt humans. Spider bites can be painful, but they rarely cause death.

For example, the Sydney funnel-web spider from Australia is very dangerous. However, since antivenom was developed in 1981, nobody has died from its bite.

You should still be careful with hairy spiders like tarantulas. When these spiders feel in danger, they protect themselves. They release a cloud of tiny hairs from their bodies. These irritating hairs can embed themselves in the skin or eyes of attackers. So it's best not to disturb these spiders or rub them the wrong way.

This common pattern in horror movies was especially popular in films from the late 20th century. The story begins with a group of teenagers having fun together. By the end, everyone is dead except for one girl. At first, this girl is usually innocent, shy, and not very strong. However, in the end, she has become the toughest and most resourceful person in the world. This last girl almost always wins.

To understand where our ability for complex language came from, we need to study how our brains are different from those of other animals. This is not just about brain size. We also need to know what other things our brains can do, and when and why they evolved that way. There are very few physical clues. The tools and objects that people from long ago left behind don't show us what speech they were capable of making.

However, we can learn something from the remains of early humans. We can see how the mouth, throat and tongue developed. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had evolved the ability to make complex sounds. Before that time, scientists who study evolution can only guess whether or not early humans communicated using more basic sounds.

Society, not nature, tells us that girls should favour arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to boys. Another problem is that young people don't see many positive female role models working in science-related jobs. Cartoons and stories often show the crazy scientist, genius inventor, or adventurous astronaut as a man.

Also, many people think that scientists are geeky, have poor social skills, or that their work is lonely and detached from the rest of the world. These are false stereotypes shown by the media, but they might make girls not identify with scientists. Girls may see science as an unattractive career path because of these stereotypes.

If girls saw more positive female role models in science, it would help them feel more confident. They would also feel a greater sense of belonging in science subjects.

The Scallion is a newspaper that comes out every week. It is free and distributed in faculty buildings. About 10,000 students read it. Students write and produce the entire newspaper themselves.

The survey shows that both university students and staff really value the newspaper. They value it for entertainment, cultural enrichment, and the work experience it provides. However, the cost of printing newspapers is significant.

Also, some students cannot easily get a copy of the newspaper. The only way to get one is to go to the university in person.

There is also an environmental problem. Many copies of the newspaper end up as litter on campus.

At Girox Foods, about 12% of our employees leave every year. This might not seem like a lot, but the industry standard is 7%. The main goal of this report is to find out what causes employee engagement within the firm. Based on those causes, we will suggest ways to improve employees' experience of the workplace and keep more employees with the company.

Much of what the speaker said seemed true. I believe there's a danger. The more connected we are, the more alone we might feel. I don't think this is a big problem for my generation. We lived without technology for a long time. We know how to be alone. And we understand that being alone is fine.

But people under 20 are a different matter. They spend so much time communicating that they never experience the feeling of being truly alone. Because of this, they might not learn how to enjoy spending time by themselves. Also, they're learning to communicate through text messages that they can edit and change before sending. This happens instead of learning the art of having real conversations with people face to face, in real time.

Don't always follow positive feedback with negative feedback. When good and bad comments often go together, people might stop valuing the good comments. They might even ignore the good comments completely.

Sometimes, give positive feedback on its own. Try not to offer suggestions for improvement every time. Positive feedback can stand alone.
